Effects_based_on_blast_pressure.text: Incendiary/Thermal effects are the fire and heat effects that occur in the immediate vicinity of the explosion.

tables.Structural Effects: Cinderblock shatters; steel structures fail; containers collapse; utility poles fail

Low_explosives.text: Produce longer incendiary thermal effects than high explosives.

High_explosive.text: Produces higher temperatures but for a shorter time.

Effects_based_on_blast_pressure.text: Incendiary/Thermal effects are the fire and heat effects that occur in the immediate vicinity of the explosion.

Low_explosives.text: Produce longer incendiary thermal effects than high explosives.

High_explosive.text: Produces higher temperatures but for a shorter time.

tables.Structural Effects: Cinderblock shatters; steel structures fail; containers collapse; utility poles fail

Low_explosives.text: Produce longer incendiary thermal effects than high explosives.

High_explosive.text: Produces higher temperatures but for a shorter time.
Produces higher temperatures but for a shorter time.

Fragmentation.text: Fragmentation occurs when pieces of the explosive device or its container come apart and are driven outward from the center of the blast. Shrapnel may be added to the device to increase the number of projectiles created by the blast. Shrapnel includes nails, marbles, ball bearings, or other materials placed in and around the device.

Blast_Effects.text: Blast-pressure effect includes a positive-pressure phase and a negative-pressure phase.

Positive_pressure.text: Moves rapidly from the point of origin of the explosion, pushing the air away from it and delivering violent force to everything in its path.

Negative_pressure.text: A vacuum/suction phase, which accounts for much of the debris near the area of greatest damage.

Positive_pressure.text: Moves rapidly from the point of origin of the explosion, pushing the air away from it and delivering violent force to everything in its path.

Negative_pressure.text: A vacuum/suction phase, which accounts for much of the debris near the area of greatest damage.
A vacuum/suction phase, which accounts for much of the debris near the area of greatest damage.

Ground_Shock.text: Ground and/or water shock is produced by the explosive shockwave being transmitted through the ground and/or water or through anything the explosive device is in contact with or buried within. If the device is in contact with a building, the shock transmits through the building walls.

Structural_Hazards.text:
Post-blast structural hazards include glass, fragment, and collapse:
Glass hazards include projected, falling, and static hazards.
Fragments include concrete, steel, and other structural components that dislodge from structures or a debris field.
Collapse hazards are created by the catastrophic failure of structural components resulting from the blast pressure. This, in turn, may result in the progressive collapse (i.e., pancaking) of a structure.

Other_Hazards.text:
Natural gas, electrical lines, and other utilities can be severed by an explosion
Contaminants, such as body fluids, may contain pathogensm.
Conventional explosives can be used to disseminate or mask dissemination of other
Chemical
,
Biological
,
Radiological
, or Nuclear hazards.
•Additional devices could be anywhere and may be placed specifically to target individuals. Terrorists use these additional devices to generate fear and panic.
